Introduction

Onchocerciasis (river blindness) is a filarial nematode infection caused by Onchocerca volvulus.  Transmission to humans occurs after several months of repeated bites by black flies (Simulium species), which breed near fast-flowing rivers and streams.  The worms mature in subcutaneous nodules and release thousands of microfilariae, which migrate through lymph, cutaneous, and ocular tissue.  Over months or years, patients often develop progressive ocular (eg, keratitis, retinitis, blindness) and cutaneous (eg, pruritus, papular dermatitis) manifestations.  Onchocerciasis is the second most common infectious cause of blindness worldwide (after infection with Chlamydia trachomatis).  The majority of cases (>99%) occur in Africa.

Risk factors



Global prevalence is estimated to be approximately 21 million, with some 200 million at risk for the disease due to ecologic and behavioral factors that increase risk of exposure:



  • Geographic:  Although some cases occur in Yemen and Central/South America, >99% of infections arise in Africa.
  • Proximity to vector habitats:  Communities near fast-flowing rivers and streams, which are the habitats of black flies, are at greatest risk.  Forested and rural areas are particularly affected.
  • Occupational/behavioral:  Work (eg, agriculture, fishing) can bring individuals near black fly breeding sites and increase the risk of exposure.
  • Lack of vector control:  Inadequate control of black fly populations increases the risk to nearby communities


In addition, limited or interrupted access to mass drug administration programs increases the risk of persistent transmission (ie, propagation of the life cycle).

Pathophysiology



Humans are infected when third-stage filarial larvae are transmitted during a bite by an infected black fly of the genus Simulium.  Because each bite transmits few larvae and adult worms require approximately 12 months to mature, infection typically results from repeated bites over many months or years.  Therefore, the illness rarely affects travelers and is much more likely to affect residents of endemic areas.



Following transmission, filarial larvae molt in subcutaneous tissue into adult worms (macrofilariae) over 6-12 months.  Female macrofilariae (often 40-60 cm in length) and male macrofilariae live in fibrous nodules (onchocercomas) in subcutaneous or intramuscular tissue overlying bony prominences of the trunk, pelvis, head, or limbs.  This is possibly because these areas are more exposed to black fly bites and the limited subcutaneous tissue facilitates oxygen diffusion for the adult worms, which may live >15 years within the fibrous nodules.



Fertilized females release 1,000-3,000 microfilariae per day; these subsequently migrate through lymph, subcutaneous, dermal, and ocular tissues, explaining the clinical manifestations.  Heavily infected individuals may harbor >100 million microfilariae.  Uptake of microfilariae during a new black fly bite propagates the life cycle.



Live microfilariae are minimally immunogenic and do not generally cause significant clinical symptoms.  In contrast, dying or dead microfilariae expose the immune system to the antigens of Onchocerca and its endosymbiotic bacteria (Wolbachia, intracellular gram-negative bacteria that live inside the nematodes and are essential for fertility).  The inflammatory response is clinically significant.  It stems from activation of the innate immune system (eg, toll-like receptors), antibody cross-reactivity, and cytokine release.  Savannah strains are particularly likely to affect the eye (eg, keratitis, chorioretinitis, blindness), whereas forest strains are more likely to affect only the skin (eg, pruritus, papular dermatitis).

Clinical presentation

Onchocercal skin disease



  • Intense pruritus is often the first and most prominent manifestation; it arises due to the immunologic response to dead/dying microfilariae in the dermis.
  • Acute/chronic papular dermatitis occurs in response to a high burden of microfilariae in the papillary dermis.  It typically begins as a scattering of small, pruritic papules, pustules, or vesicles on the shoulders or buttocks; over time, it can progress to larger, flat, pruritic papules symmetrically distributed on the waist, buttocks, and shoulders.
  • Depigmentation, particularly on the anterior shins, can lead to leopard skin (areas of depigmentation surrounded by normal areas of pigment).
  • Skin manifestations typically arise many years prior to ocular manifestations.

Ocular onchocerciasis



  • Microfilariae are present in the anterior chamber of the eye (visible on slit-lamp examination) prior to the onset of ocular pathology.
  • Punctate keratitis occurs when microfilariae die in the cornea and are surrounded by an infiltrate of leukocytes.  It causes snowflake opacities that are reversible and transient.
  • Sclerosing keratitis occurs in long-standing infections and is marked by progressive, full-thickness fibrovascular changes in the cornea.
  • Onchochorioretinitis is a common chronic finding marked by progressive inflammatory damage of the retinal pigment epithelium and underlying choroid.
  • Blindness can eventually occur in untreated cases due to corneal, chorioretinoid, and/or optic nerve damage.

Subcutaneous nodules (onchocercomas)



  • Intramuscular or subcutaneous nodules (0.5-3 cm) often arise over bony prominences (eg, iliac crest, pelvic girdle) and are generally too deep to palpate.
  • Most are asymptomatic.
  • Nodules typically have 2-3 adult female and 1-2 adult male worms.

Diagnosis



The diagnosis is typically suspected in those who have prolonged exposure (usually >12 months) to an endemic area and who have compatible clinical symptoms.  Laboratory evaluation may show peripheral eosinophilia (~70% of cases) and hypergammaglobulinemia (due to chronic antigen stimulation).  Common diagnostic tests include the following:



  • Skin snip biopsy is the gold standard.  A specimen is taken from dermal papillae over bony prominences (eg, iliac crest, scapula), incubated in saline for a day, and then examined for motile microfilariae.  It typically takes 9-15 months after transmission for the filarial burden to be great enough to have a positive skin snip biopsy result.  Therefore, early or light infection may result in a false-negative result.
  • Slit-lamp examination can visualize microfilariae in the anterior chamber of the eye or cornea.
  • Serologic tests are hampered by cross-reactivity with other filarial species and the possibility of positive serology following exposure to an endemic area in the absence of infection.  Serology is more often used for mapping prevalence and monitoring elimination efforts rather than for individual diagnosis.
  • Ultrasonography can be used to identify deep, nonpalpable nodules that contain adult worms.

Differential diagnosis



Some conditions that mimic the dermatologic or ocular features of onchocerciasis follow:



  • Loiasis (African eye worm), like onchocerciasis, is caused by a filarial nematode (Loa loa), which is transmitted during the bite of a Chrysops fly.  Endemic regions often overlap with onchocerciasis (West/Central Africa), and coinfection can occur.  Loiasis is marked by localized, pruritic/painful, transient, subcutaneous swellings (Calabar swellings).  Worms also migrate across the subconjunctiva of the eye.  Loiasis does not typically cause blindness.
  • Mansonella species are filarial nematodes endemic to sub-Saharan Africa that can cause transient subcutaneous swellings (similar to loiasis), peripheral eosinophilia, and ocular manifestations (eg, conjunctival nodules, retinal lesions).  Identifying microfilariae in blood or skin snip tests can differentiate it from onchocerciasis.
  • Leprosy can cause nodules and depigmentation but is usually accompanied by skin anesthesia, peripheral neuropathy, and acid-fast bacilli in skin smears.  Ocular symptoms can occur but are related to impaired innervation (eg, cornea drying from lagophthalmos).

Management

Individual treatment



  • Ivermectin is the treatment of choice in areas of high transmission.  A single dose is administered every 3-6 months until symptoms (eg, pruritus, rash) abate.  Doses may be required for years.  The drug selectively inhibits neurotransmission in invertebrates; it is microfilaricidal but has a limited effect on adult worms.
  • Doxycycline kills the endosymbiotic bacteria (Wolbachia) required for the survival and embryogenesis of adult worms.  It is often used with ivermectin in areas of low transmission or in travelers returning from an area of high transmission.  It is not typically used in areas of ongoing transmission because new infections would require repeated courses of doxycycline.


Alteration in the regimen may be required in the setting of Loa loa coinfection; therefore, rapid testing for loiasis is often undertaken prior to treatment.

Mass treatment



Ivermectin administered every 6 to 12 months has been shown to reduce the community burden of ocular and cutaneous onchocercal disease in areas of high transmission.  Vector eradication in areas of high transmission has also been shown to reduce disease burden in surrounding communities

Complications



Common complications of untreated onchocerciasis include:



  • Vision loss and blindness due to progressive ocular damage.
  • Skin disfigurement from lesions, atrophy, and depigmentation.
  • Social stigma and disability from disfigurement and vision loss.

Prognosis



Early treatment can prevent chronic cutaneous and ocular (eg, vision loss/blindness) complications.  Mass drug administration and vector control can reduce the incidence of new cases and complications at the community level.

) is a filarial nematode disease caused by Onchocerca volvulus following transmission during a black fly (Simulium species) bite.  The majority of cases occur in Africa in the savannah or forest regions near fast-moving rivers (black fly habitat).  Patients develop cutaneous (eg, intense pruritus, papular dermatitis, depigmentation) and/or ocular (vision loss, blindness) manifestations years after transmission due to the inflammatory response to dying microfilariae.  The diagnosis is typically made with skin snips or ophthalmologic findings.  Treatment in endemic regions involves periodic dosing with ivermectin until symptoms resolve.  Mass drug administration and vector control reduce disease burden at the community level.
